DataElement.preferredName: Person Malabsorption Syndrome Gastrointestinal Disorder Stomach/Small Bowel Excision History Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indicator of whether or not the patient has a history of malabsorption syndrome, disease affecting gastrointestinal function, or previous resection of the stomach or small bowel.

Property.preferredName: Malabsorption Syndrome Gastrointestinal Disorder Stomach Small Bowel Excision Personal Medical History
Property.preferredDefinition: A syndrome resulting from the inadequate absorption of nutrients in the small intestine. Symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea.:Diseases of the digestive tract (oral cavity to anus) and associated organs (salivary glands, liver, pancreas).:An organ located under the diaphragm, between the liver and the spleen as well as between the esophagus and the small intestine. The stomach is the primary organ of food digestion.:The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.:The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ. :an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: A syndrome resulting from the inadequate absorption of nutrients in the small intestine. Symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the gastrointestinal tract, anus, liver, biliary system, and pancreas.
The primary organ of food digestion. It is located under the diaphragm, between the liver and the spleen as well as between the esophagus and the small intestine.

The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: chronic diseases, as well as diseases and exposures associated with cancer.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Mal-absorption syndrome, dise
ReferenceDocuments.description: Mal-absorption syndrome, disease affecting gastrointestinal function, or previous resection of the stomach or small bowel.

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG Text 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have current evidence of malabsorption or chronic diarrhea or any other significant gastrointestinal disease (e.g gastrectomy, ileal bypass, Crohn's disease, gastroparesis), associated with moderate to severe diarrhea (grade 2 or more) or inability to tolerate oral therapy?

DataElement.changeDescription: Replaced retired VD with standard indicator VD and released. mc 7/23/15
